channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Superstorm survivors search for the missing
item.description: Tragic stories emerge from the havoc caused by Superstorm Sandy that left more than 140 dead from Haiti to Canada and the U.S. struggling to restore services.

item.title: Towns battered beyond recognition
item.description: Anderson Cooper reports on urgent rescue operations underway after the storm in the Northeast.

item.title: Tragic stories behind numbers
item.description: CNN's Anderson Cooper brings light to some of the victims of Superstorm Sandy.

item.title: Fuel spill after Sandy ruptures tank
item.description: The refining company Motiva has notified officials that an estimated 300,000 gallons of diesel spilled at its facility in Sewaren, New Jersey, when Superstorm Sandy pushed through, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman said.

item.title: Could plugs help?
item.description: Huge inflatable plugs -- now being developed by the federal government to protect subway tunnels from terrorist attacks -- likely could have saved some of New York's subway tunnels from storm-related flooding, according to plug developers, some of whom are wistful that development wasn't completed in time for Hurricane Sandy.

item.title: Poll: Most expect Obama win
item.description: Why wait until Election Day?

item.title: Election day unlikely to be moved
item.description: Widespread damage in the East from Superstorm Sandy threw state and local agencies tasked with running next week's election into turmoil, sending them scrambling to make sure they can accommodate voters.

item.title: Tanker explosion kills 22 in Saudi Arabia
item.description: A fuel tanker rammed into a bridge and exploded into a ball of fire Thursday, killing 22 people and sending flames sweeping over the Saudi Arabia capital, state television reported.

item.title: Report: Nigerian army guilty of abuses
item.description: Nigeria's security forces have been guilty of serious human rights abuses in their efforts to crack down on the militant Islamist group Boko Haram, Amnesty International said Thursday in a new report.

item.title: Ships sinks off Bangladesh, 100 missing
item.description: As many as 130 people may have drowned off the coast of southern Bangladesh after a boat carrying passengers seeking illegally to enter Malaysia sank in the Bay of Bengal, Bangladeshi authorities said Thursday.

item.title: Deadly storm hits southern Indian coast
item.description: At least 5,000 people were evacuated from India's southern coast Wednesday as powerful Cyclone Nilam surged in, authorities said.

item.title: Greek journalist on trial over bank list
item.description: A Greek investigative journalist went on trial Thursday over his decision to publish the names of about 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts -- a move that embarrassed Greece's political and business elite.

item.title: New debt forecasts dash Greece hopes
item.description: Athens unveils new budget projections exceeding the worst-case scenarios envisioned by international lenders when they agreed a €174bn rescue eight months ago.

item.title: Rebels: Syria using 'vacuum bombs'
item.description: An array of explosives, from shells to barrel bombs, fell on Syrian cities in another day of bloodshed Thursday, according to activists fighting to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Is Iran behind Syria drone attacks?
item.description: Syrian opposition activists say drones are giving the Assad regime a deadly advantage in bombing rebel positions and blame Tehran for supplying the hardware. CNN's Nick Paton Walsh investigates.

item.title: Halloween shooting at U.S. university
item.description: A Halloween party erupted in gunfire that left several people wounded at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, campus officials said.

item.title: Argentina drops voter age to 16
item.description: Argentinian lawmakers are debating a proposal to lower the nation's voting age to 16.

item.title: Saudi wedding tragedy as guns misfire
item.description: Celebratory gunshots sparked an electrical fire that tore through a wedding party in Saudi Arabia, killing 23 people and injuring more than two dozen others, state media reported Wednesday.

item.title: London youth fight unemployment
item.description: CNN's Erin McLaughlin looks at a British campaign to fight youth unemployment.

item.title: Italy risks economic 'vicious circle'
item.description: Italy's economy risks a "vicious circle" of weak growth and lack of confidence, the governor of the Bank of Italy has warned as unemployment rose to its highest level for 13 years while its recession deepened.

item.title: Golf: McIlroy set for Nike switch?
item.description: Rory McIlroy has cleared the path for a move to Nike after revealing he will not be renewing his current contract with Titleist.

item.title: Jeep gets stuck on border fence
item.description: Tunnels under the U.S.-Mexico border are nothing new, but authorities spotted two smugglers taking a different approach this week: driving a Jeep over the 14-foot fence dividing the two countries.

item.title: Why Election Day won't be postponed
item.description: With Superstorm Sandy leaving communities under water, stranding millions without power and consuming public resources in several states, could next Tuesday's vote for president be moved to a later date?

item.title: Sandy leaves election officials scrambling
item.description: When Sandy slammed into the East Coast on Monday, it set into motion a tight timeline for election officials: one week to ensure that voters in states from Virginia to New Hampshire would be able cast their ballots on Election Day.

item.title: Obama, Romney 'happy with polling'
item.description: Why wait until Election Day?

item.title: Looking presidential during disaster
item.description: As Sandy took aim at the East Coast, President Barack Obama discarded campaign events in Florida and Virginia to return to Washington and address the storm from the White House.

item.title: Republicans' Senate hopes dim
item.description: Even before a second Republican Senate candidate tripped over incendiary comments about rape, GOP leaders in Washington knew that their once promising chances of winning control of the Senate had diminished.

item.title: Is U.S. still leader of free world?
item.description: There was a time, not very long ago, when it seemed as if each of the world's major problems and every potential solution pivoted around the United States. The president of the United States was referred to as the leader of the free world, and the term was not used with irony or mockery.

item.title: Obama: Still Kenya's favorite son?
item.description: No one at the Railway Golf Club in the heart of Nairobi quite remembers if Barack Obama, Sr., the father of the 44th U.S. president, ever played here when he was a high-flying civil servant in the 1960s . Perhaps he played up the road at the Royal Nairobi Golf Club, the oldest of the city's six golf establishments, someone suggests.

item.title: Third party could harm candidates
item.description: Gary Johnson and Virgil Goode have no chance of winning the November 6 presidential election, but the two "third-party" candidates could have an impact on who does.

item.title: Cool Obama vs. square Romney
item.description: "Beware the fury of the patient man." -- John Dryden

item.title: 5 lessons from final U.S. debate
item.description: The final presidential debate proved to be a substantive, if not sharp, discussion on the major issues facing the U.S. as both candidates tried to win over undecided voters.

item.title: Debates over, U.S. rivals hit trail
item.description: The election day countdown starts after President Obama puts Mitt Romney on the defensive in the final debate, with analysts and a poll giving the incumbent victory.

item.title: Photos: Aftermath of Saudi truck fireball
item.description: Fuel tanker explosion kills 22 in Saudi Arabia

item.title: Power transfer: Why China 'needs a soul'
item.description: Behind the façade of unity, an intense ideological struggle is taking place among China's political elite, writes expert Xiaobo Lu.

item.title: Angola's 'ghost city': Built by China
item.description: Chinese companies have built cities out of the bush in Angola, but they have few residents. CNN's David McKenzie reports.

item.title: How supermodel scandalized a nation
item.description: All eyes were on British supermodel Jean Shrimpton as she arrived at the Melbourne Cup Carnival in 1965 -- or more accurately, the attention of a nation was focused the 22-year-old's legs.

item.title: Serena 'in awe' of sister Venus
item.description: Tennis star Serena Williams talks about her sister Venus and her all-conquering game in an exclusive interview with CNN's Open Court which will screen in full for the first time on November 22.

item.title: Go-karts: Where F1 dreams begin
item.description: It is the ultimate breeding ground for any Formula One star of the future, and a medium endorsed by one of the sport's greatest drivers, Ayrton Senna.

item.title: Could Sandy affect poll outcome?
item.description: What history tells us about how people vote after a natural disaster, and why the first few days really matter.

item.title: Sistine ceiling 500 years old
item.description: CNN's Ben Wedeman is allowed rare access inside the Sistine Chapel on the 500th anniversary of the ceiling's completion.

item.title: F1 driver's road to new victories
item.description: Alex Zanardi talks about his transition from Formula 1 driver to Paralympic Gold medalist.

item.title: U.S. election moves toddler to tears
item.description: One four-year-old girl has had enough of hearing about the presidential election.

item.title: Kick-start your career with a coach
item.description: Bill Clinton had a coach, Oprah Winfrey used one to help her get to the top of her career and, of course, top sports stars have them.

item.title: Superstorm Sandy uproots huge tree
item.description: Superstorm Sandy causes a tree to uproot in a Huntington, New York, backyard.

item.title: Heysel: Football's forgotten tragedy?
item.description: For Antonio Conti, time stopped on the evening of May 29, 1985.

item.title: Why Italians have to leave the country
item.description: As Europe's unemployment rate rises, workers in southern Italy are increasingly despondent about their prospects. CNN's Ben Wedeman reports.

item.title: Fire breaks out in flooded suburb
item.description: CNN's Brian Todd catches a fire on tape as he reports from New Jersey in the aftermath of Superstorm Sandy.

item.title: Relive horror of 'The Shining'
item.description: Neil Curry talks to critics and filmmakers of "The Shining" as the film receives a re-release in time for Halloween.

item.title: Piles of boats, mangled fun park
item.description: Helicopters capture video of the devastation along the coastline of New Jersey.

item.title: What's behind Star Wars deal?
item.description: CNN explains the $4B deal between Disney and Lucasfilm that will see new Star Wars films being made.

item.title: Singing again after lung transplants
item.description: CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta shares the story of a singer who found a new voice after two double lung transplants.

item.title: Smart money on women artists?
item.description: From Warhol's silkscreens of Marilyn Monroe to Picasso's nudes, it has generally been easier for women to be the subject of paintings than to have their own work exhibited. But the art world looks set to change, and showing increasing signs of recognition for the value and stature of leading female artists.

item.title: Lives changed forever by Sandy
item.description: Sandy disrupted the lives of millions of people when it turned toward the northeastern United States and morphed into a superstorm. Most will return to their regular routines in time, but some have been forever changed.

item.title: How Greeks cope with crisis
item.description: CNN's Diana Magnay explores the jobs crisis in Greece and the damage it's doing to the Greek economy and state of mind.

item.title: DIY furniture plan for the jobless
item.description: CNN's Fred Pleitgen on Germany's build-it-yourself furniture line for the unemployed.

item.title: Luxury shopping catches on in Iraq
item.description: A Dubai-based perfume, cosmetics and jewelry chain is set to become one of the first international luxury retailers to open its doors in previously war-torn areas of Iraq.

item.title: Tokyo's messages for Obama, Romney
item.description: People in Tokyo step up to CNN's Open Mic and deliver their messages to the U.S. presidential candidates.

item.title: 'Shining': World's scariest movie?
item.description: Neil Curry talks to critics and filmmakers of "The Shining" as the film receives a re-release in time for Halloween.

item.title: Reporter: 'Camera is my weapon'
item.description: As he strode on stage to accept the 2001 Rory Peck award for hard news journalism, Sorious Samura struggled to find the words that would fit the moment.

item.title: Ageing in the Oval Office
item.description: CNN goes week to week with presidents Clinton, Bush and Obama for their first 198 weeks in office.

item.title: Woods vs. McIIroy: The rivals
item.description: In an exclusive joint interview with CNN, the world's top two golfers discuss their growing rivalry on the fairway.

item.title: 'Fresh Prince' can still freestyle
item.description: Will Smith and Doug E. Fresh perform a freestyle rap during Gabrielle Union's 40th birthday party.

item.title: Jersey Shore 'not the same'
item.description: The New Jersey National Guard looks for displaced residents along the coastline of Seaside Heights in Sandy's aftermath.

item.title: 'Bounty' victim's mutiny inspiration
item.description: Far away from the devastation on land, Sandy battered the 'HMS Bounty,' tossing three crew into rough seas. One had told friends of her love for ship. She never made it back.

item.title: What Sandy left in wake - day two
item.description: Sandy -- the hurricane turned superstorm -- damaged homes, downed power lines and flooded streets.

item.title: Tour New York's flooded subways
item.description: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo checks out the damage left behind by Sandy inside the subway and surrounding areas.

item.title: Opinion: Don't knock 'nanny state'
item.description: It takes a disaster to remind us how much we depend on our governments, writes CNN contributor Mitchell L. Moss.

item.title: NY captivated by 'Hurri-crane'
item.description: The collapsed crane dangling over New York City is fascinating pedestrians below. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports.

item.title: Downed power lines cause blast
item.description: Downed power lines in New Jersey neighborhood caused giant sparks next to a parked car.

item.title: Raging fire destroys homes
item.description: Over 200 firefighters battle to contain a six-alarm fire in the Breezy Point section of Queens, New York.

item.title: Steve Jobs' superyacht
item.description: Just over one year after his death, a Dutch shipyard launches the late Apple chief's bespoke superyacht.

item.title: Who aged best in Oval Offic?
item.description: CNN goes week to week with presidents Clinton, Bush and Obama for their first 198 weeks in office.

item.title: Instagram: Sandy's damage
item.description: Superstorm Sandy smashed the East Coast on Monday night, triggering floods, fires and devastation. Some residents affected by the storm used the Instagram photo app to quickly post square-shaped photos showing flooding, darkened cityscapes, fallen trees and damaged structures.

item.title: Diving into Antarctic's hidden lakes
item.description: A bold project to explore an ancient lake trapped beneath an Antarctic glacier for up to half a million years may reveal the limits at which life can exist.

item.title: Why is Tanzania tops for tourists?
item.description: Home to Africa's highest mountain and one of its most famous wildlife parks, Serengeti, Tanzania is one of the continent's most popular tourist destinations.

item.title: Why do golf's 'nice guys' finish last?
item.description: "Nice guys finish last" is a mantra often preached in sport and business. Where golf is concerned, it would seem "nice guys" finish second. And they even manage to smile.

item.title: Scary work: Haunting all-year-round
item.description: Halloween is just a wild weekend for most. But for those who relish the macabre and dressing up, Oct. 31 doesn't have to spell the end to the fright season

item.title: Transformer blows in lower Manhattan
item.description: Anderson Cooper explains video from YouTube that shows a transformer explosion at a Con Ed plant in lower Manhattan.

item.title: Huge waves blast New Jersey homes
item.description: Dramatic video shows waves washing over a residential neighborhood in Ocean City, New Jersey.

item.title: Sandy buries West Virginia in snow
item.description: Superstorm Sandy buried West Virginia under snow. The state also warned about high winds and flooding.

item.title: Look presidential during a disaster
item.description: With Hurricane Sandy slamming the East Coast, President Barack Obama discarded campaign events in Florida and Virginia to return to Washington and address the nation from the White House. Meanwhile, Gov. Mitt Romney adjusted his schedule to hit the battleground state of Ohio, while directing his campaign resources in Virginia and New Hampshire to focus on storm relief.

item.title: Is sugar really that bad for you?
item.description: Every few years, there's a new food bad guy in town -- and right now, it's sugar. Some experts have even declared it a "poison" that's "killing us."

item.title: 'Why I live 60 meters up a tree'
item.description: Like many I have been anxiously waiting the outcome of the Tasmanian "forest peace talks."

item.title: iReporters share Sandy images
item.description: iReporters up and down the East Coast share their images of Superstorm Sandy.

item.title: China's 'thrifty' luxury shoppers
item.description: Until very recently, nouveau riche Chinese would not have been caught dead buying someone else's cast-offs -- even if they were Hermès.

item.title: Opinion: Prepare for more extremes
item.description: Climate change expert Chris Field argues that disaster planning must take into account rising sea levels.

item.title: Inside Tokyo's flood defense caves
item.description: Deep beneath a football field on the outskirts of Tokyo lies the city's cavernous solution to flood threats. CNN's Alex Zolbert takes a look inside.

item.title: Could plugs spare U.S. flooding?
item.description: Huge inflatable plugs -- now being developed by the federal government to protect subway tunnels from terrorist attacks -- likely could have saved some of New York's subway tunnels from storm-related flooding, according to plug developers, some of whom are wistful that development wasn't completed in time for Hurricane Sandy.

item.title: Movie spy's crazy stunts
item.description: As the latest Bond movie "Skyfall" releases, CNN explores epic action moments from 50 years of film espionage.

item.title: On the trail of a Danish 'double agent'
item.description: CNN's Nic Robertson investigates claims by a former biker that he infiltrated al Qaeda for the CIA.

item.title: Path 'led to al Qaeda leader'
item.description: A 36-year-old Dane called Morten Storm says he was the man who led the CIA to Anwar al Awlaki, the al Qaeda cleric killed in a U.S. drone strike in Yemen last year. And he says he did it with a computer thumb-drive that secretly contained a tracking device.

item.title: Brother carries Syria victim's dream
item.description: A 21-year-old Syrian who carried his young brother into Turkey after his leg was amputated has vowed to help him realize his dream of walking again. CNN's Arwa Damon tells their moving story. WARNING: Graphic content

item.title: Could frontier state decide poll result?
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explores Colorado -- an "undecided" state that has become crucially important.

item.title: Brutal Mexican drug war ignored?
item.description: Ahead of Tuesday's ballot, some Mexicans wonder why the drug war has been largely ignored by the candidates.

item.title: Superstorm Sandy
item.description: Faced with one of the most daunting recoveries imaginable, ravaged cities in the Northeast must now clean up waterlogged buildings, burned homes and crippled infrastructure -- while millions of people remain without power.

item.title: India cyclone
item.description: At least eight people were killed and thousands displaced after powerful Cyclone Nilam roared into India's southeastern coast, authorities said Thursday.

item.title: Woods, McIlroy
item.description: World No. 1 Rory McIlroy and 14-time major winner Tiger Woods are both accustomed to life on the road, but even the planet's two top-ranked golfers are not immune to the stresses and strains of the professional golf circuit.

item.title: Destinations with a dark side
item.description: The "official" night set aside for ghosts and goblins is nearly here, but if you're bewitched by the macabre and the supernatural, there are plenty of places that provide spooky sensations year-round. You won't need a costume to take in these attractions, but if you're looking for ideas on what to wear on October 31, you might find some inspiration from these historic -- and sometimes horrific -- destinations.

item.title: Hallow-meme costumes
item.description: Planning to dress as a plain old witch or scarecrow this Halloween? Sorry, that's not going to cut it anymore.

item.title: Greece strikes deal on austerity plan
item.description: Debt-stricken Greece has agreed on final details with its international creditors on the terms for the next installment of a bailout deal, the prime minister said Tuesday.

item.title: Greece, Germany: Wounds reopened
item.description: A country's economy devastated, unemployment endemic and suicides rising -- this is the reality in Greece, and there is seemingly no end in sight.

item.title: EU leaders agree on bank oversight
item.description: Leaders of the European Union in Brussels have agreed Thursday to a deal for a eurozone-wide banking supervisor in 2013 that is designed to help prevent future catastrophic bank failures that could threaten the monetary union.

item.title: Greece halted by anti-austerity strike
item.description: Tens of thousands of people rallied across Greece Thursday to protest further tough austerity measures, as a general strike essentially shut down much of the country's transportation network.

item.title: EU leaders talk fiscal union
item.description: European Union leaders are gathering at yet another summit in Brussels to discuss greater banking and fiscal cooperation in an effort to preserve the euro currency in the face of the debt crisis.

item.title: Fears over EU banking union plan
item.description: EU leaders have expressed alarm that the eurozone's push towards a banking union has stalled, setting up a confrontation with a more reluctant Germany at a European summit in Brussels.

item.title: Spain's next crisis: Regional splits?
item.description: Spain faces a test of unity over the coming months as regional elections in Catalonia and Galicia threaten to destabilize the debt-ridden nation.

item.title: Spanish budget cuts revealed
item.description: Spain will create a new fiscal authority to oversee the new spending cuts, tax increases and structural adjustments included in a new budget presented Thursday.

item.title: Anger in Athens over austerity
item.description: Elinda Labropoulou reports on the 24-hour work stoppage to protest austerity measures in Greece.

item.title: Spain: Gliding toward bailout?
item.description: Spain's Prime Minister, Mariano Rajoy, may not seem a natural performer but he appears all too familiar with the waltz; a typically slow dance, usually partnered, often mournful, with little room for improvement.

item.title: Greece's 'new poor'
item.description: With austerity measures biting hard, Greece's middle-class is slowly disappearing.

item.title: Draghi: Don't slack reforms
item.description: Earth Institute at Columbia University's Jeffrey Sachs responds to Draghi's warning to leaders at the UN.

item.title: Italian official: Exports can fix crisis
item.description: Italian Trade Promotion Agency President Riccardo Monti talks to CNN about the business climate in Italy.

item.title: Froth off Italian cappuccino demand
item.description: If life in the eurozone's economically embattled periphery was not bad enough, now the coffee culture emblematic of southern Europe is under siege. Italians are having to cut back on their cappuccinos and espressos and Spaniards are dropping their cortados, contributing to a sharp drop in wholesale coffee prices.

item.title: Cyprus to ditch the euro?
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett tackles the talks about Cyprus leaving the euro in The Number.

item.title: French PM: Give Greece more time
item.description: France has said Greece should be given more time to meet the terms of its international bailout, in the clearest call yet by a leading eurozone country for an easing of the stringent conditions attached to the €174bn rescue package.

item.title: Death and taxes in Italy
item.description: Six months ago, an Italian bricklayer behind on his taxes wrote a note to his wife of 27 years, then doused himself with gasoline and set himself on fire outside a bologna tax office. Giuseppe Campaniello died nine days later.

item.title: Ex-Greek PM: Reform takes time
item.description: Former Greek PM George Papandreou reacts to ECB's bond buying program and what it means.

item.title: Young Greeks struggle to find jobs
item.description: Georgia Pandermi is looking for her first job without luck. She's not alone. The latest Greek employment data shows that more than half of people under 25 are out of work.

item.title: Six-day work week in Greece?
item.description: Greece's creditors outline a new austerity demand in a leaked e-mail.

item.title: Trichet: Bond buying on the table
item.description: A bond-buying program to rescue debt-ridden European nations could be "justified" to counter dysfunctional markets, Jean-Claude Trichet, former European Central Bank president, has told CNN.

item.title: Europe's crisis talks on Greece
item.description: French President Francois Hollande says Greece should be given more time. CNN's Diana Magnay and Ben Wedeman report.

item.title: Should the ECB purchase bonds?
item.description: Broad agreement on the powers of the European Central Bank appears imminent, as CNN's Diana Magnay reports.

item.title: Westerwelle: Crisis is in confidence
item.description: The real crisis confronting the eurozone is regaining market confidence, not the euro, German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said Friday.

item.title: France: Greece must shape up
item.description: French President Francois Hollande restated his country's support for debt-stricken Greece Saturday, but stressed that it must live up to its reform commitments.

item.title: Helping kids understand the crisis
item.description: Portugal launches a book for kids to explain the financial crisis. But will they understand it? Isa Soares finds out.

item.title: Portuguese flee crisis to old colony
item.description: The eurozone crisis has forced many Portuguese to migrate to the former colony of Mozambique in search of jobs and economic prosperity.

item.title: Crucial meets as austerity moves bite
item.description: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras says his country, at the epicenter of a financial crisis which has hobbled Europe's common currency, is "turning the page" economically and moving toward stability.

item.title: Is Sandy a taste of things to come?
item.description: We should not be surprised. That's the view of many climate scientists as they survey the destruction wrought by the superstorm that ravaged the Northeast this week. The melting of Arctic ice, rising sea levels, the warming atmosphere and changes to weather patterns are a potent combination likely to produce storms and tidal surges of unprecedented intensity, according to many experts.

item.title: 'Why I live 60 meters up a tree'
item.description: Like many I have been anxiously waiting the outcome of the Tasmanian "forest peace talks."

item.title: Thriving deep water coral on GBR
item.description: A recent survey of the Coral Sea and Great Barrier Reef has found coral flourishing in deep waters, a stark contrast to the shallower reefs that have seen a drastic decline over the last few decades.

item.title: Cleaning up oil spills with magnets
item.description: Oil companies could soon be using an innovative new technique involving nanotechnology and magnets to help clean up offshore oil spills.

item.title: Pacific nations create marine parks
item.description: Last week, while most of the western world was focused on the approaching presidential election in the United States and a potentially disastrous hurricane making landfall in New Orleans, a group of seemingly small nations gathered on the Island of Rarotonga and changed the world.

item.title: Tasmanian Devils dying out
item.description: Taking the devilish element out of one of Australia's most iconic but endangered animals could save it from extinction.

item.title: A 'sound' idea to reduce poverty
item.description: It's a new idea which could resonate with communities across the developing world -- a biomass stove which also generates electricity using sound waves.

item.title: '$1T' fuel subsidies spark debate
item.description: Political consensus was hard to find at last month's Rio +20 Earth Summit but there was at least one group speaking with unity on the planet's environmental and economic future.

item.title: Has the electric car found its range?
item.description: Despite their green credentials, electric cars still come up short against their petrol-powered cousins when it comes to range -- how far they go before the battery needs recharging.

item.title: 'Himalayan Viagra' taking its toll
item.description: Ram Bahadur Jafra and his brothers crouch on a field, picking through blades of grass. They have traveled five days by foot to a meadow deep inside Nepal's Dolpa district. They came, as tens of thousands do each year, to harvest a highly valuable commodity: the Himalayan caterpillar fungus.

item.title: 'Crate home' thinks outside the box
item.description: Living in a house made from shipping containers isn't exactly everyone's idea of a dream home.

item.title: Floating turbine buoys offshore wind
item.description: Floating wind farms could soon be powering thousands of European homes after a prototype seaborne turbine sailed through technological trials off the coast of Agucadoura, Portugal.

item.title: Supertrees rise up in Singapore
item.description: Singapore's latest development will finally blossom later this month, with an imposing canopy of artificial trees up to 50 meters high towering over a vast urban oasis.

item.title: Chicago's no waste 'vertical farm'
item.description: An old meatpacking plant on Chicago's South Side is being transformed into an eco farm, which its founders says will produce food sustainably, while creating zero waste.

item.title: World's oceans are 'plasticized'
item.description: A marine expedition of environmentalists has confirmed the bad news it feared -- the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" extends even further than previously known.

item.title: Smog-eating tiles eat air pollution
item.description: Can the roof of your house help you breathe easier by reducing the amount of harmful pollutants from urban air?
